Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

Disk <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> rotates freely with initial angular speed <math alttext="omega sub 0 equals 22 radians per second" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>22</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>rad</mi><mo>/</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></math> about a vertical axle that passes through its center. A small vertical wheel with radius <math alttext="lowercase r sub W equals 0.040 meter" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>r</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">W</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.040</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math> is initially at rest. The wheel can rotate about a horizontal axle that passes through its center. At time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"> <mi>t</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>0</mn> </math>, the vertical wheel is pressed onto the top of Disk <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> a distance <math alttext="uppercase R sub 0 equals 0.15 meter" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>R</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.15</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math> from the disk’s center, as shown in the Side and Top Views. Both Disk <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and the wheel rotate about their axles with negligible friction. The rotational inertia of Disk <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> about its center is <math alttext="I sub 1 equals, 0.063 kilogram meter squared" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.063</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>kg</mi><mo>·</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math> and the rotational inertia of the wheel about its center is <math alttext="I sub W equals, 9.4 times 10 to the negative 4 power kilogram meter squared" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>W</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>9.4</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>kg</mi><mo>⋅</mo><msup><mtext>m</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msup></mstyle></math>.

The magnitude of the force of friction between Disk <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and the wheel is modeled by the function <math alttext="uppercase F sub lowercase f equals A times e to the negative B t power" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi>f</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mi>A</mi><msup><mi>e</mi><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mi>B</mi><mi>t</mi></mpadded></msup></math>, where <math alttext="A equals 12 newtons" overflow="scroll"><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi></math> and <math alttext="B equals 2.3 inverse seconds" overflow="scroll"><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2.3</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mpadded></msup></math>.

Disk <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> has mass <math alttext="lowercase m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> and rotational inertia <math alttext="I sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> about its center. When the center of Disk <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is a distance <math alttext="uppercase R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math> from the center of Disk <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, Disk <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is dropped onto Disk <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, as shown in Figure <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math>. At time <math alttext="t sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, both disks are rotating together without slipping.
